text: the ruling from the European Court of
Justice in the past couple of hours who
have said that Britain can put a stop to
breaks it without the consent of other
EU Member States and listening to the
ruling for us was Adam Fleming who joins
us now from Luxembourg tell us more
about the ruling Adam and what it means
so this case was brought by a group of
British parliamentarians who are at the
UK Parliament at Westminster at the
Scottish Parliament and the European
Parliament and they wanted some clarity
about article 50 of the EU treaty that's
the exit clause which the UK is using to
leave the EU and it says what happens if
the country wants to leave but isn't
clear about what happens and what
conditions there are if a country
changes its mind and today the judges
here at the EU stop court the European
Court of Justice in Luxembourg have said
that if a country chooses to leave it
does that unilaterally it should have
the same right to change its mind and
reverse its decision unilaterally
without having to speak to the other 27
member states without having to get
their permission and not giving them an
opportunity to attach any strings to
that revocation so that means in theory
if the UK had a parliamentary vote or
another referendum or a general election
which changed its position on brexit and
meant it wanted to stay in it could do
that no questions asked and its terms of
its membership would not change so the
UK would not be obliged to join the
single currency the euro during the
passport-free area known as the Schengen
zone or give up its rebate on the EU
budget which the people who brought this
case who are opponents of brexit think
is a powerful argument to make to MPs at
Westminster before they make the
decision on whether to vote for Theresa
Mays deal tomorrow I would also be a
powerful argument in the minds of the
public if they are asked again what they
want to do in another referendum Adam
always good to see you thanks for
joining us from outside the
